Award.AwardTitle: Travel Grants for US Scientists to Attend Metabolic Pathway Analysis 2013 Conference at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, England on September 16-20, 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1346586
Carlson, Ross P.

This award supports the participation of US investigators and graduate students in the Metabolic Pathway Analysis meeting to be held in Oxford, UK from Sep. 16-20, 2013. The meeting has a primary focus on the structural (topological) analysis of metabolic networks, and in particular techniques allied to linear algebra, linear programming and computer modelling. This focus may be applied at many levels of abstraction, from individual reaction mechanisms, through pathways, organelles, whole organisms and, most recently, mixed populations. Covered topics will include Metabolic pathway analysis, Metabolic flux analysis, Elementary mode analysis, Metabolic modelling, Metabolic engineering, Genome scale modelling. One day will be devoted to Thermodynamics in Metabolism.

NSF support will help ensure the success of the meeting by partially defraying conference costs for select US academic scientists and engineers with an emphasis on underrepresented groups and graduate students. In the absence of NSF support, many US academic scientists and graduate students would not be able to attend and to benefit from interactions with the international community of metabolic analysis/engineering researchers.

The award from the Biotechnology, Biochemical, and Bioengineering Program of the CBET Division is co-sponsored by the Synthetic and Systems Biology Program of the Molecular and Cell Biology Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Applied biology and the study of fundamental topics including biofuels synthesis, environmental remediation, and human health have undergone a major transition during the past couple decades. Biology has largely become an information and systems science due to rapid developments in the ‘omics’ sciences including genomics, metabolomics and proteomics. Extracting biologically meaningful knowledge from these omics databases is often limited by computational tools highlighting the necessity for developing new theory and in silico applications.  The Metabolic Pathway Analysis 2013 conference, held in Oxford, England, focused on theory, methodologies and applications of computational approaches to decode biological principles found in the omics data sets. Historically, this conference series has not been well attended by US-based scientists due to the airfare cost associated with international travel. The poor attendance limited the transfer of these important data and methods to US researchers and limited the establishment of international collaborations.

This NSF travel grant provided airfare travel assistance to eleven US systems biology researchers, based on a submitted application packet, to enable them to attend the Metabolic Pathway Analysis 2013 conference. The US-based researchers included four graduate students, two post-doctoral research scientists, one research technician, two early stage professors and two established professors. This attendance increased US-based scientist representation by approximately 300% relative to the previous three conferences in the series. All supported scientists presented either an oral or a poster presentation and participated in the numerous lectures, breakout discussions and social events. NSF provided airfare travel support but the awardees were responsible for covering their own conference registration, local transportation, food and lodging expenses.

The award outcomes included 1) the education of eleven US-based scientists in the newest computational approaches for studying metabolic pathways, 2) the dissemination of US-based scientists’ approaches and data to an international audience, and 3) the opportunity for US-based scientists to establish new professional contacts and collaborations through the face-to-face discussions over the course of five days.
